description: From Middle French conservatif, from Latin cōnservō (“to preserve”). Equivalent to conserve +‎ -ative.

adjectives.description: conservative (comparative more conservative, superlative most conservative)

examples: The chef added a conservative amount of salt to the dish.

entries.meaning: Tending to resist change or innovation.
examples: The curriculum committee at this university is extremely conservative.
At a conservative estimate, growth may even be negative next year.

entries.meaning: (US, economics, politics, social sciences) Supporting some combination of fiscal, political or social conservatism.
(Britain, politics) Relating to the Conservative Party.
examples: We have always been conscientiously attached to what is called the Tory, and which might with more propriety be called the Conservative, party.

entries.meaning: (physics, not comparable) Neither creating nor destroying a given quantity.
Having power to preserve in a safe or entire state, or from loss, waste, or injury; preservative.
(clothing) Conventional, traditional, and moderate in style and appearance; not extreme, excessive, faddish, or intense.
(medicine) Not including any operation or intervention (said of a treatment, see conservative treatment)

definitionGroups.group: A person who favors maintenance of the status quo.

entries.meaning: (politics) One who opposes changes to the traditional institutions of their country.
(US, politics) A person who favors decentralization of political power and disfavors interventionist foreign policy.
